tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires deriving the natural frequency, involving dynamics and spring force concepts. It requires multiple steps to set up the equation of motion and solve for the frequency, and the image is essential for understanding the geometry.

answer_validation.reasoning: Take small rotation \(\theta\) of the rigid, massless L-shaped rod about the pin. The mass \(m\) is at coordinates \((L, H)\) from the pivot, so its distance from the pivot is \(r = \sqrt{L^2 + H^2}\). For small rotation, its vertical displacement is \(y_m = r\,\theta\) (arc length approximation). The spring is attached at the mid-point of the horizontal segment, at distance \(L/2\) from the pivot. Its vertical displacement is therefore \(y_s = (L/2)\,\theta\). The spring force is \(F_s = k y_s = k (L/2)\theta\). This force produces a restoring moment about the pivot: \(M_s = F_s (L/2) = k (L/2)^2 \theta = k L^2 \theta /4\). The only inertia is due to the point mass: its mass moment of inertia about the pivot is \(I = m r^2 = m(L^2 + H^2)\). Applying rotational equation of motion about the pivot, \(I\,\ddot{\theta} + M_s = 0\) gives \(m(L^2 + H^2)\ddot{\theta} + (k L^2/4)\theta = 0\). Comparing with standard SDOF form \(I\ddot{\theta} + K_{\text{eq}}\theta = 0\), the natural circular frequency is \(\omega_n = \sqrt{K_{\text{eq}}/I} = \sqrt{\dfrac{k L^2}{4 m (L^2 + H^2)}}\). The natural frequency in Hz is \(f_n = \omega_n/(2\pi) = \dfrac{1}{2\pi}\sqrt{\dfrac{k L^2}{4 m (L^2 + H^2)}}\), which matches option A.

step_by_step: Identify the generalized coordinate: choose a small rotation \(\theta\) of the rigid rod about the pinned end as the single degree of freedom.

Compute the inertia: the rod is massless, so only the point mass m contributes. Its distance from the pivot is \(r = \sqrt{L^2 + H^2}\), hence its mass moment of inertia is \(I = m r^2 = m(L^2 + H^2)\).

Relate spring deflection to \(\theta\): the spring is attached at mid-span of the horizontal part, at distance \(L/2\) from the pivot. For small rotation, its vertical displacement is \(y_s = (L/2)\theta\).
Find restoring moment from the spring: spring force is \(F_s = k y_s = k (L/2)\theta\). Its moment arm about the pivot is \(L/2\), so restoring moment is \(M_s = F_s (L/2) = k L^2 \theta /4\).
Write rotational equation of motion about the pivot: inertia moment + restoring moment = 0 for free vibration, giving \(m(L^2 + H^2)\ddot{\theta} + (k L^2/4)\theta = 0\).

Compare with standard SDOF form \(I\ddot{\theta} + K_{eq}\theta = 0\) to identify \(I = m(L^2 + H^2)\) and \(K_{eq} = k L^2/4\). Hence \(\omega_n = \sqrt{K_{eq}/I} = \sqrt{\dfrac{k L^2}{4 m (L^2 + H^2)}}\).
Convert to frequency in Hz: \(f_n = \omega_n/(2\pi) = \dfrac{1}{2\pi}\sqrt{\dfrac{k L^2}{4 m (L^2 + H^2)}}\), which corresponds to option A.

topic.name: Mechanical vibrations of discrete systems
topic.syllabus_ref: Structures and Vibrations -> Free and forced vibrations of single degree of freedom systems

concepts.name: Equivalent rotational stiffness from linear spring
Mass moment of inertia of point mass

essential: Basic rigid body kinematics and small-angle approximation
Mass moment of inertia of a point mass about a pivot
Equation of motion for SDOF rotational systems
Concept of natural frequency for undamped free vibration
helpful: Understanding of generalized coordinates in vibration problems

Main Concept: requires: Mass moment of inertia of discrete masses
requires: Relationship between linear and angular displacement (y = l theta)
enables: Modeling complex aeroelastic components as SDOF systems
enables: Analysis of control surface flutter and hinge dynamics

difficulty_factors: Requires recognizing that only the point mass contributes to inertia
Needs correct identification of spring point location (L/2) and its effect on rotational stiffness

textbook_references.author: S. S. Rao
textbook_references.text_snippet: For a single rotor on a massless shaft, the equation of motion is Ip theta_ddot + K_t theta = 0, giving omega = sqrt(K_t / Ip).

video_references.professor: Prof. S.K. Dwivedy and Prof. Rajiv Tiwari
video_references.topic_covered: Natural frequency of a rigid member with springs (SDOF rotational system)

video_references.professor: Prof. S.K. Dwivedy and Prof. Rajiv Tiwari
video_references.topic_covered: Single-degree-of-freedom torsional system with a disc on a massless shaft

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Choose generalized coordinate \(\theta\) \u2192 find inertia of mass about pivot \u2192 relate spring deflection to \(\theta\) \u2192 compute restoring moment \u2192 write rotational equation of motion \u2192 extract natural frequency \u2192 convert to Hz and match option
key_insights: The rod is massless, so only the point mass contributes to inertia.
Linear spring at distance l from pivot gives rotational stiffness \(k l^2\).
Small-angle approximation lets us write vertical displacement as length times angle.

formulas_principles.name: Mass moment of inertia of a point mass
formulas_principles.conditions: Mass m at distance r from rotation axis
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute rotational inertia of the attached mass about the pin.

formulas_principles.name: Small-angle linear-angular displacement relation
formulas_principles.conditions: Small rotation \(\theta\) in radians at radius l
formulas_principles.relevance: Relates vertical displacement of spring and mass to rotation of the rod.

formulas_principles.name: Hooke's law for linear spring
formulas_principles.conditions: Linear elastic spring with stiffness k and deflection y
formulas_principles.relevance: Gives spring force from its vertical deflection.

formulas_principles.name: Natural frequency of rotational SDOF system
formulas_principles.conditions: Undamped free vibration of single-degree-of-freedom rotational system
formulas_principles.relevance: Core formula to compute natural circular frequency from equivalent stiffness and inertia.

industry_examples: Control surface hinge dynamics in aircraft, where aerodynamic surfaces are supported by springs or actuators and have concentrated masses.
Landing gear doors or access panels modeled as rigid links with springs to estimate their vibration characteristics.
specific_systems: Elevator or aileron mass-spring balancing mechanisms
Rotorcraft pitch links and control rods
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Estimating natural frequencies of such SDOF rotational systems helps avoid resonance with engine orders, aerodynamic excitations, or ground vibrations, which is critical for structural integrity and passenger comfort.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the mass m directly in \(\omega_n = \sqrt{k/m}\) without converting to rotational form with moment of inertia and rotational stiffness.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They recall the standard mass-spring formula and overlook that this is a rotational SDOF system.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: First decide whether the motion variable is linear or angular. For angular motion, always work with moment of inertia and moments, not just mass and forces.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to completely wrong dependence on L and H and wrong option choice.

common_mistakes.mistake: Taking the spring lever arm as L instead of L/2 when computing rotational stiffness.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They focus on the total length to the mass and ignore the actual spring attachment point at mid-span.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Carefully read the figure and mark distances from the pivot to each force application point before writing moments.
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives rotational stiffness four times too large, leading to option C instead of A.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using only L for the distance of the mass from the pivot, ignoring the vertical offset H.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They may think only horizontal distance matters since the rod is drawn horizontally.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always compute the actual radial distance from the pivot using Pythagoras when the mass is offset in both x and y directions.
common_mistakes.consequence: Underestimates inertia and overestimates natural frequency.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Rotational SDOF: "I and K, not m and k"
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remember to use moment of inertia I and rotational stiffness K_eq for angular vibration problems.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Whenever you see a pivoted rigid body with springs or masses.

flashcards.front: For a point mass m at distance r from a pivot, what is its mass moment of inertia about the pivot?
flashcards.back: The mass moment of inertia is \(I = m r^2\).

flashcards.front: A linear spring of stiffness k is attached at distance l from a pivot. For small rotation \(\theta\), what is the equivalent rotational stiffness?
flashcards.back: Vertical deflection is \(y = l\theta\). Spring force is \(F = k y = k l \theta\). Moment about pivot is \(M = F l = k l^2 \theta\). Thus rotational stiffness is \(K_{eq} = k l^2\).

flashcards.front: In the GATE rod-spring-mass system, why does the natural frequency depend on \(L^2 + H^2\)?
flashcards.back: Because the mass is at coordinates (L, H) from the pivot, so its distance from the pivot is \(r = \sqrt{L^2 + H^2}\), and inertia is \(I = m r^2 = m(L^2 + H^2)\).

flashcards.front: What is a quick check to ensure you used the correct lever arm for a spring in rotational vibration problems?
flashcards.back: Trace from the pivot to the exact point where the spring force acts and measure that distance; do not confuse it with the distance to the mass or other points.

real_world_context.application: Modeling hinge dynamics of aircraft control surfaces supported by springs or actuators.
real_world_context.industry_example: An elevator surface may be mass-balanced and supported by torsion springs. Its small-angle vibration about the hinge can be approximated as a rigid body with equivalent rotational stiffness and inertia.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect estimation of natural frequency can lead to resonance with aerodynamic excitations, causing flutter or structural fatigue.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize it as a standard SDOF rotational vibration problem. Write inertia and rotational stiffness quickly; no numbers are given, so it is purely symbolic and algebraic.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure, prefer options where k is in numerator, m in denominator, and L appears squared in both stiffness and inertia terms; H should appear only in inertia (L^2 + H^2).
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to finish within 2 minutes: 1 minute to set up geometry and moments, 1 minute to derive \(\omega_n\) and match the option.

search_keywords: single degree of freedom rotational vibration
massless rod with end mass natural frequency
rigid bar with spring small oscillations
moment of inertia point mass about pivot

alternative_methods.name: Energy (Lagrange) method
alternative_methods.description: Define generalized coordinate \(\theta\). Write kinetic energy \(T = \tfrac{1}{2} m (L^2 + H^2) \dot{\theta}^2\) and potential energy \(V = \tfrac{1}{2} k (L/2)^2 \theta^2\). Apply Lagrange's equation \(\dfrac{d}{dt}(\partial T/\partial \dot{\theta}) + \partial V/\partial \theta = 0\) to obtain the same equation of motion and natural frequency.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Systematic and easily extendable to multi-DOF systems; less chance of sign errors. Cons: Slightly longer for simple SDOF problems compared to direct torque balance.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when multiple masses and springs are present or when forces are conservative and easier to express via potential energy.

connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Control surface dynamics and stability often use simplified SDOF rotational models to estimate response to gusts or pilot inputs.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: The natural frequency derived here is the undamped pole of a second-order system, directly related to closed-loop dynamics when feedback is added.
connections_to_other_subjects.Space Dynamics: Attitude control of spacecraft appendages (e.g., solar panels) can be approximated as rigid bodies with torsional springs at hinges.

deeper_dive_topics: Lagrangian formulation for multi-degree-of-freedom vibration systems
Aeroelastic flutter analysis of control surfaces modeled as rigid bodies with springs
Effect of damping on rotational SDOF response and resonance

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Free and forced vibrations of single degree of freedom systems
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent conceptual question testing understanding of equivalent rotational stiffness and inertia in SDOF vibration models.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided related material on SDOF torsional systems, rigid members with springs, and rotor-shaft systems. While not exactly the same geometry, they reinforced the core idea: equation of motion for rotational SDOF systems with equivalent stiffness K_eq and inertia I. The specific L-shaped geometry and use of L/2 came from internal reasoning.

future_questions_potential: Ask for the effect of adding a second spring at a different location on the rod and derive the new natural frequency.
Include a finite mass for the rod and require computing its contribution to the moment of inertia.
Introduce damping at the pivot and ask for the damped natural frequency and logarithmic decrement.
Ask students to model the same system using Lagrange's equations instead of torque balance.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: A rigid massless rod pinned at one end has a mass m attached to its other end. The rod is supported by a linear spring of stiffness k as shown in the figure. The natural frequency of this system is:
